title.narrative: EnRoute: Towards a living income of farmers to tackle child labour

description.narrative: ETG sources UTZ/RA certified cocoa and implements a broad variety of sustainability initiatives with its suppliers, from farmer training to CLMRS (child labour monitoring and remediation systems) and agroforestry projects. Building on lessons learned from sustainability initiatives tackling living income (LI) gap, and child labour (CL) within the cocoa domain, ETG is committed to mainstream best practices in its coffee and cashew supply chains as well. The living income has become a key indicator to express poverty whenever a gap exists between the LI and households' actual income. As such, the LI gap is likely to be a strong indicator for child labour, as poverty is widely considered to be both the one of the main root causes of child labour, as well as a result. While data on these key indicators has started to be available in IVC and Togo, though less reliable in Togo, the project aims to collect such data and have reliable living income proxies to best decide which intervention can have a positive output on improving LI and reducing CL. Following data collection and analysis, the project intends to put into place and compare two sets of interventions with the purpose of increasing living income levels. The interventions will be defined according to data analysis from phase A. So far, the suggested approaches are: 1. Supporting smallholder farmers through traditional agricultural services to intensify the production of their cash crops and diversify their income to improve their resilience to market volatility and environmental shocks. 2. Piloting higher payments to farmers for their produce, as a potentially more effective alternative to the current development model revolving around costly farmer training and agricultural extension services.
